title: Astro-E
name: Astro-E
descript:
Astro-E was to be the Japan’s fifth X-ray astronomy mission, but was lost during launch on 10 Feb 2000. Astro-E was developed at the Japanese Institute of Space and Astronautical Science (ISAS) in collaboration with the US and Japanese institutions. Astro-E was to carry, among other instruments, a new type of X-ray spectrometer, the X-ray micro-calorimenter, which would have provided an unprecendent energy resolution compared to non-dispersive instruments.

The mission was rebuild as ASTRO-E2, renamed Suzaku, that was successfully launched in 2005 and operated for 10 years.

instruments.name: X-ray Telescope (XRT)
instruments.descript: Five nested conical thin-foil grazing incidence telescopes, all gold-coated. Four were XRT-I used for the XIS instrument, the fifth XRT-S served the XRS instrument.

instruments.name: X-ray Spectrometer (XRS)
instruments.descript: An X-ray microcalorimeter composite of 32 pixels at the foci of the XRT-S

instruments.name: X-ray Imaging Spectrometer (XIS)
instruments.descript: Four 1024×1024 pixel CCD detectors at the foci of one of the XRT-I. Three are front illuminated (FI), one is back illuminated (BI).

instruments.name: Hard X-ray Detector (HXD)
instruments.area:
∼145 cm2 at 15 keV (PIN)
315 cm2 at 100 keV (GSO)
instruments.descript: GSO crystal scintillator (>30 keV) & silicon PIN diodes (<60 keV)
